Award.AwardTitle: Unraveling the Genomic and Molecular Basis of the Dive Response: Nitric Oxide Signaling and Vasoregulation in the Weddell Seal
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Weddell seal is a champion diving mammal. The physiology that permits these animals to sustain extended breath-hold periods and survive the extreme pressure of diving deep allows them to thrive in icy Antarctic waters. Key elements of their physiological specializations to breath-hold diving are their ability for remarkable adjustment of their heart and blood vessel system, coordinating blood pressure and flow to specific body regions based on their metabolic requirements, and their ability to sustain periods without oxygen. Identifying the details of these strategies has tremendous potential to better inform human medicine, helping us to develop novel therapies for cardiovascular trauma (e.g. stroke, heart attack) and diseases associated with blunted oxygen delivery to tissues (e.g. pneumonia, sepsis, or cancer). The goal of this project is to document specific genes that control these cardiovascular adjustments in seals, and to compare their abundance and activity with humans. Specifically, the investigators will study a signaling pathway that coordinates local blood flow. They will also use tissue samples to generate cultured cells from Weddell seals that can be used to study the molecular effects of low oxygen conditions in the laboratory. The project will further the NSF goals of training new generations of scientists and of making scientific discoveries available to the general public. The project will train a pre-veterinary student researcher will conduct public outreach via a center for community health improvement, a multicultural affairs office, and a public aquarium.

The goal of this study is to unravel the molecular mechanisms underlying the dive response. A hallmark of the dive response is tissue-specific vascular system regulation, likely resulting from variation in both nerve inputs and in production of local signaling molecules produced by blood vessel cells. The investigators will use emerging genomic information to begin to unravel the genetics underlying redistribution of the circulation during diving. They will also directly test the hypothesis that modifications in the signaling system prevent local blood vessel changes under low oxygen conditions, thereby allowing the centrally mediated diving reflex to override local physiological responses and to control the constriction of blood vessel walls in Weddell seals. They will perform RNA-sequencing of Weddell seal tissues and use the resulting sequence, along with information from other mammals such as dog, to obtain a full annotation (identifying all genes based on named features of reference genomes) of the existing genome assembly for the Weddell seal, facilitating comparative and species-specific genomic research. They will also generate a Weddell seal pluripotent stem cell line which should be a valuable research tool for cell biologists, molecular biologists and physiologists that will allow them to further test their hypotheses. It is expected that the proposed studies will advance our knowledge of the biochemical and physiological adaptations that allow the Weddell seal to thrive in the Antarctic environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary - The goal of this project was to study molecular mechanisms that allow Weddell seals to dive deep in icy polar waters. To do this, seals must withstand prolonged periods of low oxygen levels (hypoxia) in blood and tissues, and control blood flow (perfusion) to key locations throughout the body. We discovered that vasoconstriction (contraction in blood vessels to limit blood flow through them) during diving is aided by reduction of local hypoxia signaling processes that would typically exist in terrestrial animals. Seals have a lower abundance and activity of guanylyl cyclase compared to terrestrial mammals, which reduces the ability of their blood vessels to respond to relaxation and dilation signals such as nitric oxide. This project also studied the genome of the Weddell seal to identify features supporting their elite diving ability, namely their cardiovascular specializations and resistance to hypoxia. We found that sequences of the guanylyl cyclase protein differed between Weddell seals and terrestrial mammals, potentially affecting their structure and function. This experiment also uncovered differences between Weddell seal tissues in nitric oxide vasodilation signaling that help explain how some tissues (brain) can receive priority for blood flow during diving. On the other hand, we found that tissues more likely to experience reduced blood flow during diving (kidney) had higher protective antioxidants than other tissues in the Weddell seal. This study also identified a global protective strategy that may help seals avoid inflammatory stress. Interleukin 6 cytokine production (a marker of inflammation) during a controlled experiment in blood cells was 500-fold lower in Weddell seals compared to healthy humans. Seal blood serum also protected mouse, seal and human cells from inflammation, suggesting a yet-to-be-determined anti-inflammatory component of seal blood. A study of the Weddell seal genome identified several genes that may be involved in cell protection, control of blood flow and cardiovascular regulation in this species, which suggest new targets for future work.

 

Intellectual merit - The goal of this study was to move forward our understanding of the cellular mechanisms that underlie the mammalian dive response using genomic and molecular approaches. These represent levels of biological organization that have been largely absent from prior studies in the field of diving physiology. This approach has expanded our basic understanding of the regulation of blood flow, inflammation and tolerance to low oxygen levels within Weddell seal tissues. This has relevance both within the realm of diving physiology, contributing to our understanding of molecular mechanisms and the evolutionary path of diving mammals, and may facilitate future insights that inform new therapeutic protocols for human disease and syndromes associated with low oxygen. Scientific resource development associated with this project include the annotation of the Weddell seal genome and its inclusion in the "100-vertebrates" genome alignment. Additional tissue-specific sequencing (of mRNA and microRNA transcripts) are now publicly available resources.

 

Broader impacts - This project trained undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdoctoral researchers in the lab and in the field. Trainees were included in all outreach activities, including skype conversations with classrooms from the field, in-person visits to local classrooms, and hosting student visits to the laboratory. In collaboration with the New England Aquarium, we designed a high school level teacher guide on the topic of the mammalian dive response, which is available online. To coincide with publication of this teacher's guide, we prepared a workshop for high school teachers on site at the New England Aquarium to introduce the lecture and laboratory materials. The project team also presented public lectures and university seminars to disseminate the project findings and to share experiences from the field.
